    > I would like to hear everyones thoughts on the topic.  
    > Your point about AT's
    > is well taken.
    > 
    > To my way of thinking, flawed though it might be, a unit 
    > describes one
    > scenario of one behavior.  For example, if we're talking 
    > about an ordering
    > system, a specified product might exist in a number of 
    > states, onhand and
    > not committed, on hand but committed, on order (imminent 
    > arrival), on order
    > (protracted arrival), out of stock at the supplier (undetermined
    > availability) or perhaps even never available again.  A 
    > customer wanting to
    > order that product might have patterned responses for 
    > each of these states.
    > If the task at hand is to develop a system that will 
    > automate the response
    > to a customer placing an order for this item, each 
    > possible state and
    > outcome combination constitutes a unit.  Each test case 
    > contributing its
    > behavioral rules to the design.

I don't know, Jason.  It seems to me that unit is, for all intensive
purposes, the class to be tested.  If all of these scenarios are present in
that one class, then they can be tested at the "unit" level.  If the
scenarios are a combination of objects and their interactions, I think the
test raises to the "acceptance" level.  The thing I take issue with is your
use of the term 'scenarios', because it conjures up ATs in my mind, but that
may just be me.

It all comes down to what is the best way to write unit tests.  Right?
That's a heated discussion from which I have learned to stay away (for the
most part).  Everyone has their style and most are very adamant about it.
There are some general principles that we can all agree upon, but once that
is done, the proofs are more or less stylistic.

Some general principles can be found at
<http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-12-2000/jw-1221-junit-2.html>.  I
don't agree with the all of the things listed there, but most of it sounds
good and right to me.

-Jason
